value.displayName: Localized swelling, mass and lump, neck (finding)

translation.displayName: Localized swelling, mass and lump, neck

tr.td:
Basic Information
Time seen: Date & time 2021-11-06 10:20:00.
History source: Patient.
Arrival mode: Private vehicle.
History limitation: None.
Additional information: Chief Complaint from Nursing Triage Note : Chief Complaint
2021-11-06 9:52 EDT Chief Complaint Throat pain, seen yesterday and did not get medications filled and did not call to schedule follow up with Dr. Jain
2021-11-05 10:39 EDT Chief Complaint upper/lower gi scope on 8/4/2; throat swelling started last night; swelling to throat and neck this morning .

History of Present Illness
The patient presents with NECK SWELLING SINCE THIS AM. PT SEEN YESTERDAY FOR FACIAL SWELLING AFTER HAVING AN EGD AND ESOPHAGEAL DILITATION BY DR. JAIN. CT SOFT TISSUE NECK DONE YESTERDAY, DR. JAIN CONSULTED AND RX'D BENTYL AND F/U IN OFFICE. WOKE THIS MORNING WITH SWELLING IN THE NECK, DIFFICULTY SWALLOWING, BILATERAL EAR PAIN. SUBJ FEVER. The onset was TODAY. The course/duration of symptoms is constant and worsening. The character of symptoms is pain and swelling. The degree at onset was minimal. The degree at present is moderate. Risk factors consist of RECENT EGD. Therapy today: none. Associated symptoms: fever and DIFFICULTY SWALLOWING.

Review of Systems
Constitutional symptoms: Fever.
Skin symptoms: Negative except as documented in HPI.
ENMT symptoms: Ear pain, DIFFICULTY SWALLOWING.
Respiratory symptoms: Cough, BEGAN THIS MORNING.
Cardiovascular symptoms: Negative except as documented in HPI.
Gastrointestinal symptoms: Negative except as documented in HPI.
Genitourinary symptoms: Negative except as documented in HPI.
Musculoskeletal symptoms: Negative except as documented in HPI.
Neurologic symptoms: Negative except as documented in HPI.
Psychiatric symptoms: Negative except as documented in HPI.
Additional review of systems information: All other systems reviewed and otherwise negative.

COMPARISON: None available.FINDINGS:Single portable AP view of the chest. The heart is enlarged. The lungs are clear. Nopneumothorax or pleural effusion.IMPRESSION:No acute findings or significant changesDictated by:Scott BabinDictated DT/TM: 2021-11-05 12:09 PMSigned by: Scott BabinSigned DT/TM: 2021-11-05 12:10 PMEditor: DT/TM:
CT Neck Soft Tissue W (2021-11-05 13:01)
Result: Name: MONEEKA P GWYNMRN: V000677130FIN: V2121700578Accession No: 07CT210012959Sex: Female DOB: 1971-10-16 Age: 50 yearsStudy Date/Time: 2021-11-05 11:20 AMStudy Description: CT Neck Soft Tissue WAttending Physician: MD-EMR MELISSA LYTTLE WELCHOrdering Physician: MD-EMR MELISSA LYTTLE WELCHReferring Physician: SELF REFERRED PHYPrimary Care Physician: MD-EMR MELISSA LYTTLE WELCH HISTORY: 50-year-old with throat swelling status post endoscopyTECHNIQUE: CT of the neck, soft tissues with contrast. Coronal and sagittal reconstructions wereobtained. Radiation dose reduction techniques included automated exposure control orexposure modulation based on body size. COMPARISON: None available.FINDINGS: There is no significant pharyngeal asymmetry. There are no enhancing lesions in thevisualized supratentorial or infratentorial spaces. Globes, lenses and retrobulbarcontents are normal. The lung apices are clear. There are no acute or destructiveosseous lesions. There are scattered spondylitic changes. There is chronic paranasalsinus thickening most involving the left maxillary sinus. The mastoids are clear. Thethyroid and salivary glands are normal. There are no pathologically enlarged lymphnodes in the neck nor bilateral supraclavicular spaces. Vascular enhancement isnormal. There is no flow-limiting bilateral ICA stenosis. There is no subcutaneousemphysemaIMPRESSION: No evidence of perforation mass or enlarged lymphadenopathyDictated by:Scott BabinDictated DT/TM: 2021-11-05 1:53 PMSigned by: Scott BabinSigned DT/TM: 2021-11-05 1:58 PMEditor: DT/TM:
R648-5189-8776 -- 2021-11-06 09:41
CR Chest 1 Vw (2021-11-06 10:57)
Result: Name: MONEEKA P GWYNMRN: V000677130FIN: V2121800457Accession No: 07CR210022459Sex: Female DOB: 1971-10-16 Age: 50 yearsStudy Date/Time: 2021-11-06 10:46 AMStudy Description: CR Chest 1 VwAttending Physician: APRN-EMR Nicole RICHARDSOrdering Physician: APRN-EMR Nicole RICHARDSReferring Physician: SELF REFERRED PHYPrimary Care Physician: APRN-EMR Nicole INDICATION: Throat pain and neck swelling. COMPARISON: Chest radiographs from yesterdayFINDINGS:Single portable AP view of the chest. Stable cardiomegaly. Mediastinal contours alsoremain unchanged. Tracheobronchial tree is clear. Lungs are adequately inflated andclear. No focal consolidation. No pneumothorax or pleural effusion. No acute osseousfindings. IMPRESSION:No acute findings.Dictated by:Sejal PatelDictated DT/TM: 2021-11-06 11:12 AMSigned by: Sejal PatelSigned DT/TM: 2021-11-06 11:15 AMEditor: DT/TM:
CR Esophagram (2021-11-06 14:14)
Result: Name: MONEEKA P GWYNMRN: V000677130FIN: V2121800457Accession No: 07CR210022478Sex: Female DOB: 1971-10-16 Age: 50 yearsStudy Date/Time: 2021-11-06 1:19 PMStudy Description: CR EsophagramAttending Physician: APRN-EMR Nicole RICHARDSOrdering Physician: APRN-EMR Nicole RICHARDSReferring Physician: SELF REFERRED PHYPrimary Care Physician: APRN-EMR Nicole 40215INDICATION: Pain in the neck. Recent esophageal dilation.TECHNIQUE: Single contrast Gastrografin esophagram was performed.COMPARISON: None available.FINDINGS:ESOPHAGUS: Motility: Mild esophageal dysmotility. Mucosa: Unremarkable. No evidence of esophageal perforation. Distensibility: Normal.GASTROESOPHAGEAL JUNCTION: No evidence of hiatal hernia.GASTROESOPHAGEAL REFLUX: None observed.Fluoroscopic time: 0.8 minutes, 30 image acquired.IMPRESSION: No evidence of esophageal perforation.Dictated by:Ryan Currier, MDDictated DT/TM: 2021-11-06 2:37 PMSigned by: Ryan Currier, MDSigned DT/TM: 2021-11-06 2:38 PMEditor: DT/TM:
CT Neck Soft Tissue W (2021-11-06 14:26)
Result: Name: MONEEKA P GWYNMRN: V000677130FIN: V2121800457Accession No: 07CT210013019Sex: Female DOB: 1971-10-16 Age: 50 yearsStudy Date/Time: 2021-11-06 1:19 PMStudy Description: CT Neck Soft Tissue WAttending Physician: APRN-EMR Nicole RICHARDSOrdering Physician: APRN-EMR Nicole RICHARDSReferring Physician: SELF REFERRED PHYPrimary Care Physician: APRN-EMR Nicole RICHARDSHISTORY: Worsening neck swelling.TECHNIQUE: CT of the neck, soft tissues with contrast. Coronal and sagittal reconstructions wereobtained. Radiation dose reduction techniques included automated exposure control orexposure modulation based on body size. COMPARISON: CT soft tissue neck from yesterday and 2020-01-23; and esophagram from earlier today.FINDINGS: No acute findings within the imaged brain. Moderate mucosal thickening of the leftmaxillary sinus.Enlarged adenoids, similar to exam from 2019, which could be related to chronicadenoiditis. The palatine and lingual tonsils are within normal limits. Enlargeduvula, also stable since 2019. There is narrowing of the adjacent airway. Epiglottisand aryepiglottic folds are unremarkable. Vocal cords are symmetric without softtissue nodularity. Base of the tongue is unremarkable. Salivary glands are symmetric.Mildly prominent, however subcentimeter in short axis cervical lymph nodes, whichcould be reactive. Major arteries of the neck are patent.Mild soft tissue swelling of the submandibular subcutaneous fat and fascia is newsince yesterday. No organized drainable collections.Hyperdense contrast within the oropharynx and esophagus from recent esophagram. Noextraluminal contrast within the field-of-view.No acute fracture or traumatic listhesis. Prevertebral soft tissues are within normallimits. No retropharyngeal abscess.Trachea is patent. Lung apices are well-aerated.IMPRESSION: 1. Mild soft tissue edema involving the submandibular region without an organizedcollection. Otherwise, no significant interval change since yesterday.2. Enlarged adenoids, similar to 2019, which could be related to chronic adenoiditis.3. Enlarged uvula with narrowing of the adjacent airway. Please correlate for sleepapnea.Dictated by:Sejal PatelDictated DT/TM: 2021-11-06 2:40 PMSigned by: Sejal PatelSigned DT/TM: 2021-11-06 2:56 PMEditor: DT/TM:
.

Course: unchanged.
Pain status: unchanged.

Notes: pt states PAIN IS UNCHANGED. NO DECREASE IN SWELLING OF NECK. DR. JAIN PAGED.

Impression and Plan
Diagnosis
Neck swelling - Discharge, Medical
Swallowing painful - Discharge, Medical
Calls-Consults
- Phone call, 1300 SPOKE WITH DR. JAIN, WANTS ME TO CALL ENT FOR CONSULT, SPOKE WITH ENT AT U OF L, DR. SMOTHERS. WANTS ESOPHAGRAM UNDER FLUOR TO RULE OUT PERFORATION AND REPEAT CT SOFT TISSUE NECK WITH CONTRAST. CALL HIM BACK WITH RESULTS. .
Plan
Condition: Stable.
Disposition: Discharged
Admit/Transfer/Discharge:
Discharge (Order): Start: 2021-11-06 15:54 EDT, Discharge to: Home.
Prescriptions: Prescription Writer
Pharmacy:
Benadryl 25 mg oral tablet (Prescribe): 25 mg, 1 Tab, Oral, TID, for 5 Day(s), PRN: as needed for allergy symptoms, 24 Tab, 0 Refill(s)
predniSONE 50 mg oral tablet (Prescribe): 50 mg, 1 Tab, Oral, Daily, for 5 Day(s), 5 Tab, 0 Refill(s).
Patient was given the following educational materials: Dysphagia, Dysphagia.
Follow up with: SANJAY JAIN Within 2 to 3 days Call for follow up appointment
Return if condition worsens.
Counseled: Patient, Regarding diagnosis, Regarding diagnostic results, Regarding treatment plan, Regarding prescription, Patient indicated understanding of instructions.
Notes: 1520: SPOKE WITH U OF L ENT , DR. LAMB, WANTS CT SOFT TISSUE NECK AND ESOOPHAGRAM POWER-SHARED TO U OF L AND THEN HE WILL CALL ME BACK.
SPOKE WITH RADIOLOGIST WHO READ CT SOFT TISSUE NECK. NO ACUTE FINDINGS. ESOPHAGRAM ALSO NEGATIVE, 1550 SPOKE WITH DR. LAMB WITH ENT AGAIN. HE REVIEWED CT SOFT TISSUE NECK AND ESOPHAGRAM. AGREES PT CAN GO HOME WITH GI F/U NEXT WEEK AND STEROIDS. PT REQUESTED FOOD AND IS EATING WITHOUT DIFFICULTY.

Radiology Reports

tr.td: THOMAS, ALICIA A, CT TECHNOLOGIST - CT Scan-ME;

item.paragraph: (CT Neck Soft Tissue W) Reason For Exam: WORSENING NECK SWELLING. NEEDS REPEAT CT

paragraph.content:
Name: MONEEKA P GWYN
mrn:R032028035
fin:c2656260712
accession no:36ek360336406
Sex: Female DOB: 1971-10-16 Age: 50 years
Study Date/Time: 2021-11-06 1:19 PM
Study Description: CT Neck Soft Tissue W
Attending Physician: APRN-EMR Nicole
Ordering Physician: APRN-EMR Nicole
Referring Physician: SELF REFERRED PHY
Primary Care Physician: APRN-EMR Nicole
HISTORY:
Worsening neck swelling.
TECHNIQUE:
CT of the neck, soft tissues with contrast. Coronal and sagittal reconstructions were
obtained. Radiation dose reduction techniques included automated exposure control or
exposure modulation based on body size.
COMPARISON:
CT soft tissue neck from yesterday and 2020-01-23; and esophagram from earlier today.
FINDINGS:
No acute findings within the imaged brain. Moderate mucosal thickening of the left
maxillary sinus.
Enlarged adenoids, similar to exam from 2019, which could be related to chronic
adenoiditis. The palatine and lingual tonsils are within normal limits. Enlarged
uvula, also stable since 2019. There is narrowing of the adjacent airway. Epiglottis
and aryepiglottic folds are unremarkable. Vocal cords are symmetric without soft
tissue nodularity. Base of the tongue is unremarkable. Salivary glands are symmetric.
Mildly prominent, however subcentimeter in short axis cervical lymph nodes, which
could be reactive. Major arteries of the neck are patent.
Mild soft tissue swelling of the submandibular subcutaneous fat and fascia is new
since yesterday. No organized drainable collections.
Hyperdense contrast within the oropharynx and esophagus from recent esophagram. No
extraluminal contrast within the field-of-view.
No acute fracture or traumatic listhesis. Prevertebral soft tissues are within normal
limits. No retropharyngeal abscess.
Trachea is patent. Lung apices are well-aerated.
IMPRESSION:
1. Mild soft tissue edema involving the submandibular region without an organized
collection. Otherwise, no significant interval change since yesterday.
2. Enlarged adenoids, similar to 2019, which could be related to chronic adenoiditis.
3. Enlarged uvula with narrowing of the adjacent airway. Please correlate for sleep
apnea.
Dictated by:Sejal Patel
Dictated DT/TM: 2021-11-06 2:40 PM
Signed by: Sejal Patel

text.paragraph: No data available for this section
No data available for this section

Dysphagia
Dysphagia is trouble swallowing. This condition occurs when solids and liquids stick in a person's throat on the way down to the stomach, or when food takes longer to get to the stomach than usual.
You may have problems swallowing food, liquids, or both. You may also have pain while trying to swallow. It may take you more time and effort to swallow something.
What are the causes?
This condition may be caused by:
• Muscle problems. They may make it difficult for you to move food and liquids through the esophagus, which is the tube that connects your mouth to your stomach.
• Blockages. You may have ulcers, scar tissue, or inflammation that blocks the normal passage of food and liquids. Causes of these problems include:
◦ Acid reflux from your stomach into your esophagus (gastroesophageal reflux).
◦ Infections.
◦ Radiation treatment for cancer.
◦ Medicines taken without enough fluids to wash them down into your stomach.
• Stroke. This can affect the nerves and make it difficult to swallow.
• Nerve problems. These prevent signals from being sent to the muscles of your esophagus to squeeze (contract) and move what you swallow down to your stomach.
• Globus pharyngeus. This is a common problem that involves a feeling like something is stuck in your throat or a sense of trouble with swallowing, even though nothing is wrong with the swallowing passages.
• Certain conditions, such as cerebral palsy or Parkinson's disease.
What are the signs or symptoms?
Common symptoms of this condition include:
• A feeling that solids or liquids are stuck in your throat on the way down to the stomach.
• Pain while swallowing.
• Coughing or gagging while trying to swallow.
Other symptoms include:
• Food moving back from your stomach to your mouth (regurgitation).
• Noises coming from your throat.
• Chest discomfort with swallowing.
• A feeling of fullness when swallowing.
• Drooling, especially when the throat is blocked.
• Heartburn.
How is this diagnosed?
This condition may be diagnosed by:
• Barium X-ray. In this test, you will swallow a white liquid that sticks to the inside of your esophagus. X-ray images are then taken.
• Endoscopy. In this test, a flexible telescope is inserted down your throat to look at your esophagus and your stomach.
• CT scans and an MRI.
How is this treated?
Treatment for dysphagia depends on the cause of this condition, such as:
• If the dysphagia is caused by acid reflux or infection, medicines may be used. They may include antibiotics and heartburn medicines.
• If the dysphagia is caused by problems with the muscles, swallowing therapy may be used to help you strengthen your swallowing muscles. You may have to do specific exercises to strengthen the muscles or stretch them.
• If the dysphagia is caused by a blockage or mass, procedures to remove the blockage may be done. You may need surgery and a feeding tube.
You may need to make diet changes. Ask your health care provider for specific instructions.
Follow these instructions at home:
Medicines
• Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your health care provider.
• If you were prescribed an antibiotic medicine, take it as told by your health care provider. Do not stop taking the antibiotic even if you start to feel better.
Eating and drinking
• Follow any diet changes as told by your health care provider.
• Work with a diet and nutrition specialist (dietitian) to create an eating plan that will help you get the nutrients you need in order to stay healthy.
• Eat soft foods that are easier to swallow.
• Cut your food into small pieces and eat slowly. Take small bites.
• Eat and drink only when you are sitting upright.
• Do not drink alcohol or caffeine. If you need help quitting, ask your health care provider.
General instructions
• Check your weight every day to make sure you are not losing weight.
• Do not use any products that contain nicotine or tobacco, such as cigarettes, e-cigarettes, and chewing tobacco. If you need help quitting, ask your health care provider.
• Keep all follow-up visits as told by your health care provider. This is important.
Contact a health care provider if you:
• Lose weight because you cannot swallow.
• Cough when you drink liquids.
• Cough up partially digested food.
Get help right away if you:
• Cannot swallow your saliva.
• Have shortness of breath, a fever, or both.
• Have a hoarse voice and also have trouble swallowing.
Summary
• Dysphagia is trouble swallowing. This condition occurs when solids and liquids stick in a person's throat on the way down to the stomach. You may cough or gag while trying to swallow.
• Dysphagia has many possible causes.
• Treatment for dysphagia depends on the cause of the condition.
• Keep all follow-up visits as told by your health care provider. This is important.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
